author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: Interesting to see the ~20% full block rate (compared to the Deribit estimate of ~5% full blocks): https://insights.deribit.com/market-research/analysis-of-eip-2593-escalator/

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: To me this suggests that either increasing to the upper limit (e.g. target 15M but allow up to 45M), or in-protocol Escalator may make sense.

author: timbeiko
content: there are some 51% attacks issues if we have a cap >2x the target

author: pietjepuk
content: I'd personally wait to see what happens until _after_ the merge, when block times are hopefully a lot more consistent

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: Is the risk that a miner winning multiple blocks in a row could produce some very large / computationally intensive blocks due to repeated gas limit increases?

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: and while the opportunity cost for a sub-51% miner to mount an attack is quite high, then cost to a miner that sets a different gas target is very low. sub-51% miners are likely enough to win multiple blocks in quick succession.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: would decoupling gas target and gas limit (so they change at different rates) mitigate this?

author: .vbuterin
content: I think these attacks are more severe in the <2x case than in the >2x case

author: .vbuterin
content: eg. if limit/target = 1.5, then 33% of miners making empty blocks could push the basefee down to zero

author: .vbuterin
content: But if limit/target = 3, then sure, 33% of miners making full blocks could push the basefee up to infinity, but their cost in doing so would also go up to infinity

author: .vbuterin
content: So it's not a realistic attack in the same way

author: .vbuterin
content: Post-merge pushing limit/target up to 3 because we lose poisson variance so we get some extra slack is definitely something really worth considering

author: timbeiko
content: If we want to consider this, we probably need to answer "can clients handle 45m gas blocks fairly well post-merge" pretty quickly after it happens!

author: .vbuterin
content: Clients can already handle two 22.5m gas blocks one after the other due to poisson variance, right?

author: timbeiko
content: Also, curious how you'd tradeoff increasing the limit to 3x vs. increasing the target a bit?

author: .vbuterin
content: Hmm

author: .vbuterin
content: Increasing the target is obviously ideal, but that increases sustained load and not just burst load, and I know people have more concerns about sustained load at the moment

author: timbeiko
content: Right, but given ~20% of blocks are full (as per that paper), I wonder when the two loads "intersect"

author: timbeiko
content: Basically, if you are guaranteed to have 3x the target every 5 blocks (maybe less because you empty out the txn pool earlier), by how much can the gas limit increase to have the same equivalent load?

author: timbeiko
content: I guess with today's numbers, it means we roughly see 90m gas/5 blocks. If we raise the cap, we'd maybe see 105m/5 blocks, so is that better or worse than splitting the extra 15m over the 5 blocks evenly and raising the gas limit 3m ðŸ¤”
